data.title: Rogue Rover
data.solution:
import sys
import math

# Initialize:
EAST = 0
SOUTH = 1
WEST = 2
NORTH = 3
orientation = EAST

ax, ay = 0, 0
bx, by = 0, 0

# Input:
W, H = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
for y in range(H):
    row = input()
    for x in range(W):
      if row[x] == '>':
        ax, ay = x, y
      elif row[x] == 'X':
        bx, by = x, y

dx = bx - ax
dy = by - ay

moves = ""
rotate = 0
# Horizontal:
if dx < 0:
  rotate = WEST
orientation += rotate

moves += "R " * rotate 
moves += "F " * abs(dx)

# Vertical:
if dy < 0:
  rotate = NORTH - orientation
elif dy > 0:
  rotate = (SOUTH - orientation) % 4
else:
  rotate = 0
orientation += rotate

moves += "R " * rotate
moves += "F " * abs(dy)

print(moves[:-1])
data.statement:
<<STORY:>>
The satellite that used to remotely control the rover you're in was destroyed by a passing comet.

You manage to turn on a monitor with an aerial view of the place you're in (An ASCII map with: '{{.}}'s representing the lunar plains, '{{>}}' your position and '{{X}}' the base's position), and after racking your head for a few minutes you can only remember two basic commands:

<<COMMANDS:>>
'{{F}}' to Move forward one unit
'{{R}}' to Rotate 90 degrees clockwise (to the right)

Using only these two commands can you find a way to get back to the lunar base '{{X}}' from your Rover '{{>}}'?

<<IMPORTANT:>>
The Rover always starts looking EAST (To the right)
Astronaut protocol dictates that you FIRST move on the HORIZONTAL axis and THEN move on the VERTICAL axis

<<EXAMPLE:>>
Input:
"4 1"
"X..>"
Solution:
"R R F F F"
Rotate 180 degrees (= Rotating 90 degrees to the right twice) in order for the rover to be facing west.
Move Forward 3 times to reach the base.

Goal

STORY:
The satellite that used to remotely control the rover you're in was destroyed by a passing comet.

You manage to turn on a monitor with an aerial view of the place you're in (An ASCII map with: '.'s representing the lunar plains, '>' your position and 'X' the base's position), and after racking your head for a few minutes you can only remember two basic commands:

COMMANDS:
'F' to Move forward one unit
'R' to Rotate 90 degrees clockwise (to the right)

Using only these two commands can you find a way to get back to the lunar base 'X' from your Rover '>'?

IMPORTANT:
The Rover always starts looking EAST (To the right)
Astronaut protocol dictates that you FIRST move on the HORIZONTAL axis and THEN move on the VERTICAL axis

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"4 1"
"X..>"
Solution:
"R R F F F"
Rotate 180 degrees (= Rotating 90 degrees to the right twice) in order for the rover to be facing west.
Move Forward 3 times to reach the base.
Input
Line 1: Two integers separated by a space W and H , W for the width of the map and H for the height of the map

Next H lines: A string of W characters, either '>' for the rover's initial position, 'X' for the base's position or '.' for the lunar plains
Output
The commands the rover has to follow: a mix of 'R's and 'F's separated by a space.
First output the instructions that move the rover in the horizontal plane and after the instructions that moves it on the vertical plane.
Constraints
1 ≤ W, H ≤ 20
Example
Input
7 1
>....X.
Output
F F F F F
